bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.E.S. Thorpe, October 14, 1919

div1.p: Carter writes about the relationship between impounded water and malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.E.S. Thorpe, October 14, 1919
div1.opener:
Impounded Waters
Tallassee Power Co.
Badin, N. C.
Confidential
Baltimore, Md.,
October 14, 1919.
Mr. J. H. S. Thorpe,
General Superintendant,
Tallassee Power Company,
Badin, N. C.
Dear Mr. Thorpe:
div1.p:
I wish to acknowledge your check for $123.11 in full for my
expenses as witness in the Jane Elliott case.

We, the Public Health Service, purpose to continue the investiga-
tions of impounded waters for certainly two years more--probably for
two intensively and three more for special features. Whether the
one purposed at High Rock is suitable for our purpose, I cannot now
tell, but will know--or some one of us will know--by next spring.

One thing about such waters--no matter what is done, the impound-
ing of water on a large scale (and to a less degree on a small one) will
affect the incidence of malaria in its environment, lessening it in
some places and increasing it in others. The same is true of any. at
random, disturbance of the earth's surface: Railroads: county roads etc.
Of course these statements only apply in sections warm enough for Ano-
pheles to breed and become infective to men--i. e. in potential malarial
areas.

Now the general effect of pondage is to make more malaria than it
removes: (1) by changing the location of breeding places of Anopheles
so that they will be nearer residences than they were before (see .
marked passage in pamphlet enclosed: (2) by changing the proportion of
-2-
the species of Anopheles prevalent in the community. This latter
is more important than the first. The breeding places destroyed by
the pond may be those of Anopheles quadrimaculatus or of A. puncti-
pennis. Those made by it are mainly--almost exclusively--A. quadri-
maculatus. Now A. quadrimaculatus is unquestionably a more dangerous
insect from a malarial point of view than A. punctipennis--far more
so, and they fly further. An increase, and it is usually a large in-
crease, in A. quadrimaculatus closer to residences will do more harm
than the diminution of a larger number of A. punctipennis at a great-
er distance, or even at the same distance, will do good. In general
then, the impounding of water in a malarial region increases the a-
mount of malaria.

I am telling you all this so that you may know the general effect
of impounding water on its environment--especially for future ponds.
I think there is no question that in the community close to such parts
of the Tallassee Lake as are covered by floatage there will be a de-
cided increase of malaria from Anopheles quadrimaculatus bred in the
lake. I judge that from the number of A. quadrimaculatus found in
the houses last fall.

This condition of breeding can be controlled by oiling such col-
lections of floatage, or by fluctuation of the pond level. The former
is quite expensive and naturally would have to be kept up every sum-
mer: the latter is. I judge, impracticable--at least to lower the
level enough to lodge all floatage.

In planning a new pond then, it seems to me that the most feasible
method of meeting these conditions, which will certainly arise, would
-3-
be (a) to allow for the damage to health in the purchase of the
flowage rights or (b) to purchase all the land that will be af-
fected. Note two things in (a)--(1) that the health damage to
the land only affects residence on it, not its value in agriculture
otherwise: (2) that lands will be damaged which are not flooded at
all if the residences on them are close enough to the breeding places
made by the pond. This would be equity anyway.

For the present ponds I think equity would justify damages to
the adjacent community, but not based on the total destruction of
the value of the land at $75.00 per acre. The verdict seems to have
been at the rate of $20.00 per acre. I presume the land is worth
$15.00 and part of that is lost by inability to reside on it during
the malaria season.

- The preparation of the area (edges) to be covered by a pond can
minimixe the amount of malaria which it will produce, as can stocking
with fish etc. but I know no way by which it can be entirely prevented--
that is, within economical limits. The most satisfactory way is, I
think, to move people off from it.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
